DIV1.P: Proper LESSONS FOR THE TORIES, TO BE Read throughout the Year.

PROPER LESSONS FOR THE TORIES, TO BE Read throughout the Year: But more particularly upon June 10 The Birth-Day of the PRE∣TENDER, alias the Fugitive Hero, July 1. The Day on which the Battle of the BOYNE (in Ireland) was fought; when K. JAMES ran away from his Army, and left them to shift for themselves.
August 1. The CRISIS: Or, The Day of K. GEORGE's most happy Acces∣sion to the Crown.
November 4. The Day on which K. WIL∣LIAM (of ever blessed Memory) was born; and upon which, He, and his Feet arriv'd in TORBAY, in the West of England.
LONDON: Printed, and Sold by J. Roberts, near the Oxford-Arms in Warwick-Lane. 1716

DIV2.HEAD: CHAP. I.
DIV2.P: I. THERE liv'd a King in the land of Britain, whose Name was JAMES.
II. The same was a bad Prince, and he did that which was Evil in the Sight of the Lord; he started aside lik a crooked Bow, and obey'd not the Commandments of his God.
III. But went a whoring after strange Gods, even the Works of Mens Hands; he set up Images in the Tabernacles, and bended his knee before them, defiling thereby the Temple of the most High.
IV. Morover, he oppressed the People, he laid heavy Burdens upon their Backs, and prepar'd a Yoke to gaul the Necks of the Righteous.
V. He had no Son to inherit the Land, but yielding to the Devices of JEZEBEL his Queen; he consented to all she did, and own'd a spurious Issue to be his Legitimate Heir, and call'd his Name JAMES.
VI. This provoked the anger of the Lord; and He stirr'd up a Prince against him, who shou'd spoil him of all his Lands.
VII. Now it came to pass, that Prince WILLIAM having espous'd MARY, the eldest Daughter of JAMES.
VIII. That the chief of the Nobility and Gentry sent unto him, and said,
IX. Rise up, we pray thee, and come a∣mong us: Save and deliver the People of the true God, and suffer them not to be in Thral∣dom for ever.
X. Whereupon he presently arose, and gather'd unto him certain of his Host, and said unto them;
XI. Let us help those who are in Distress, and shake of the Bonds of those who are in Captivity, and restore the true Worship of the Lord.
XII And he pass'd over into the Land of BRITAIN, and came into the West Part thereof, and there were daily gathered unto him such as should be SAVED
XIII. Moreover, he put forth a Decla∣ration, saying, I come not to conquer the Kingdom, but to restore the true Worship of the God of our Fore-fathers.
XIV And the People cast up their Hats, and shouted for Joy, and crying aloud, said,
XV. This is a blessed Day, we will re∣joyce and be merry in it.
XVI. NOW, when these Tidings were brought unto JAMES the King, who was then at Dinner;
XVII. He arose from his Chair, and stand∣ing up, said unto those who were round a∣bout him, What shall we do?
XVIII. And then he sat down again, and fill'd his Belly, and it is recorded he was a great Eater;
XIX. And his chief Counsellors said un∣to him, Let us go forth unto Battle,
XX. And he said, We will go forth; but his Heart fail'd him.
XXI HOWBEIT, in a few Days, he call'd unto him certain of the Chieftains, and Men of War.
XXII. And he spoke unto them saying,
XXIII. Let us make ready for Battle, and go forth to meet those who shall oppose us.
XXIV. And they march'd towards the Plains of SALISBURY.
XXV. And, behold, as he slept, he saw a Vision; and lo an old Man cloath'd in white Arrayment, appear'd before him, and said, Return, for the Lord is not with thee.
XXVI. From this Day the Kingdom is rent from thee, and given unto another: even unto a Prince thy Kinsman, who serveth the Lord in Spirit, and in Truth.

DIV2.HEAD: CHAP. II.
DIV2.P: I. VVHen the King awoke, he was sore troubled in mind.
II. And having Eaten and Drunken plen∣tifully, he said unto those who were near him,
III. I have seen a Vision, and it pleas∣eth me not; I will, therefore, arise, and re∣turn unto the Place from whence I came, for I will tarry here no longer.
IV: And he 'rose up, and returned unto his Palace.
V, Now he tarried but a short Space be∣fore he sent away his Queen Jezebel, and his supposed Son James unto a Neighbouring King.
VI. And he himself retired to another Part of his Dominions, called Hibernia.
VII. Now it came to pass, That Prince William marched toward the Capital City of Britain;
VIII. And the chief Rulers and Elders of the Kingdom being assembled together, did Vote and Consent, that the Prince and his Spouse Mary should be King and Queen thereof.
IX. And they were annointed by the High Priest in the midst of all the Cong∣regation, and the Oil ran down even unto the Skirts of their Cloathing.
X. And they did that which was Righte∣ous in the Sight of the Lord, and turned out those who had defiled the Temple.

DIV2.HEAD: CHAP. III.
DIV2.P: I. JAMES being come into the King∣dom of Hibernia, did gather unto him Thousands and Ten Thousands of such who had drank with him of the Cup of A∣bomination.
II. And he trusted unto the Multitude of his Host, unto his Pike-men, and his Horse∣men, and divided them into Troops, and in∣to Companies, of Fifties, and of Hundreds, and placed Captains over them.
III. And he said unto them, Go ye forth into the North∣part of the Kingdom, and destroy all those who shall stand before ye.
IV. And they did as their Master com∣manded them; For they spared neither Male nor Female, neither had they any Regard unto the Cries of the Widows and the Or∣phans.
V. Now, when these things came unto the Ears of the Children of Inniskelling, they armed themselves, and said.
VI. We will fight the Battle of the Lord; It is better to fall by the Sword, than to fall into the Hands of the Wicked.
VII. And howbeit, they were but an Handful, yet they annoyed the Camp of heir Enemies, and slew many of them.
VIII. But the Number of the Wicked increased, and the Children of Inneskilling were put to Flight, and they fled unto the City of Derry, and entered in at the Gates thereof.
IX. And the Host of the Wicked follow∣ed after them, and came and pitched their Tents before the Walls of the City.
X. And they summoned them to surrender saying, Yield ye your selves Prisoners, while it is yet well with ye,
XI. But they answered with one Accord, We will not yield.
XII. So the City was besieged, and every Thing was very dear therein, for there was a Famine among them.
XIII. Insomuch, that a Dog's Head was sold for half a Crown, and a Rat for six∣pence.
XIV. And some of the People began to murmure. and cry, Let us open the Gates, and yield unto them who are encamped against us, for there is plenty of good things among them.
XV. Then stood up the Governour who was also one of the Priests of the Temple, and said,

XVI. Men and Brethren, know ye not
that we have a Saying, which is handed down unto us from our Forefathers, who themselves received it from the Mouth of the Godly;
XVII. Blessed are they who hold out unto the end.
XVIII. Who is he, therefore, that will seek his own Destruction, and Despise the Coun∣sel of the Righteous?
XIX. And they Answered and said,
XX. We will not dwell in the Tents of the Ungodly, neither will we have Communion with the Wicked
XX. And from thence forward they liv'd together as Brethren, and trusted in the Lord their God to save them.

DIV2.HEAD: CHAP. IV.
DIV2.P: I. NOW, when these Tidings were brought unto King WILLIAM, he said,
II. Let us go forth and Assistour Brethren, for they are of the Houshold of Faith.
III. And he made himself ready, and pass'd over into the North-part of HIBERNIA, and Landed at a Town call'd CARICK∣FERGUS.

IV. But such was the Care and Vigilance
of the good King, that he sent before him a Ship well stor'd with all Things necessary for the Relief of the City of DERRY.
V. And she sail'd into the Mouth of the River; but there was a Boom laid cross the same, so that she cou'd not come near.
VI. And they, who were in the City, ima∣gin'd that the Ship did belong unto the E∣nemy, and that she was sent to Attack them by Sea:
VII. Therefore, they fir'd their Cannon against her, and did Damage unto her;
VIII. But at length they perceiv'd she was their Friend, and she broke the Boom, and came into the Harbour of the City;
IX. And they rejoic'd exceedingly, and were glad; giving Thanks for such timely Succour.
X. But when the Wicked had heard, what good Things had happen'd unto those who were in the City, they were astonish'd:
XI. And they struck their Tents, and fled (like a Thief) in the Night, and hasten'd unto their Master JAMES.
XII. In the Morning, when they, who defended the City, intended to have salli'd forth.
XIII. They perceiv'd that their Enemies were gone; and there was no more of them.
XIV. They consulted, therefore, among themselves, what was most proper to be done
XV. And they tarry'd a while in the City and repair'd the Breaches and Damages there of, and took Care of such as were Sick and Wounded.
XIV. And they left a good Garison there in, and furnish'd it with all Things which were requisite for its Defence, and marched to join King WILLIAM.
XVII. And forasmuch as there had been many Londoners among them, and by Rea∣son that all who were therein, acquitted themselves like Men.
XVIII. The City was no longer call'd DERRY, but LONDON-DERRY.

DIV2.HEAD: CHAP. V.
DIV2.P: I. KING WILLIAM having paci∣fy'd the Troubles in the North-part of the Kingdom, march'd towards Dub∣lin, which was the head City thereof.
II. But as he came near unto the Town of Drougheda, he perceiv'd that the Ene∣mies of the Lord were encamp'd on the o∣ther side of the River, which is call'd the BOYN.
III. And having held a Council of WAR, it was resolv'd, that the Army shou'd cross over (if possible) and drive the Enemy from their Entrenchments.
IV. Now it came to pass, that some of the Men had found a Place which was ford∣able.
V. And as King WILLIAM was put∣ting his Men in ARRAY, the Enemy fir'd against him, and a Bullet graz'd upon his Shoulder;
VI. Whereupon it was straitway rumour∣ed, the King was killed.
VII. This alarm'd all the Host, insomuch that many of their Hearts fail'd them, and their Countenances fell.
VIII. But the good King hearing there∣of, shew'd himself among them; and pulling off his Hat, said, I am but slightly wounded.
IX. Then the Horsemen pass'd over the River, and drove the Enemy from their Trenches.
X. As soon as JAMES saw what they were doing, he call'd his Men about him, and said.
XI. Behold the undaunted Spirit of Eng∣lish-Men, whose Bellies being fill'd with Beef, and their Stomachs with Pudding, will slay e∣very one of ye, except ye provide for your selves.

XII. Haste, therefore and run; Follow
me, for I will tarry no longer here.
XIII. And Fear came upon them all: And they fled, albeit, they were by Thous∣ands more in Number than the Servants of the Lord.
XIV. That Night JAMES lay in DUBLIN.

DIV2.HEAD: CHAP. VI.
DIV2.P: I. THere was an Evil Counsellor who was call'd TYRCONNEL, and he said unto JAMES,
II. Let us, I pray thee remove from hence, and go into another Country;
III. But before we depart, we will set Fire to this City, and lock up the Gates thereof, and then burn all the Protestants therein.
IV. The Wrath of JAMES was kindl'd at this, and he would not consent un∣to it, but said,
V. I have been too wicked already and vio∣lated my Oath, provoking thereby the Judg∣ment of Heaven;
VI. And shall I add Murder to my Breach of Faith? Who is he that adviseth me so to do?
VII. Thus the City was sav'd, and JAMES fled unto the King of the GAULS, from whom he crav'd Assistance.
VIII. Now tho' JAMES was fur∣nish'd with Men and Necessaries;
IX. Yet he ca'd not to go along with them but sent them into the Kingdom of HIBER∣NIA, while he himself tarry'd with JEZE∣BEL, and her Bastard.
X. For he was infatuated, and bewitch∣ed with her Sorceries, and could not get out of the Pit into which she had drawn him.
XI. And by him the Scripture was fulfil∣led, saying, A Whore is a deep Ditch, and he who is abhorr'l of the Lord shall fall therein.
XII. Now King WILLIAM had re∣duced to Obedience the Major part of the Kingdom of HIBERNIA;
XIII. But the City of LIMMERICK held out against him, and it was besieg'd, and taken at last by Capitulation.
XIV. He fought the Battle at AUGH∣RIM, in which the French General, who was called St. RUTH, was kill'd with a Can∣non Ball.
XV. And he discomfited them, and put them to Flight; and leaving the Kingdom in Peace, appointed Governors over it; and returned to LONDON, which is the Me∣tropolis of GREAT-BRITAIN.

DIV2.HEAD: CHAP. VII.
DIV2.P: 1. A War being proclaim'd between WIL∣LIAM, King of Britain; and LEWIS, King of the GAULS,
II. The STATES of HOLLAND, and divers Princes and Potentates enter'd into a Confederacy against LEWIS, who aim'd at an universal Monarchy;
III. And they drew their Armies forth, and the Seat of the War was in FLAN∣DERS.

IV. About this Time dy'd Queen MA∣RY; and there were Lamentations and Mournings for her in all Parts of the King∣dom, for she was belov'd of her Subjects, and had done that which was Righteous in the Sight of the Lord.
V. However, the War was carry'd on, Battles were fought, and Towns were tak∣en; and they, who were slain, were many in Number.
VI. At length, the King of the GAULS u'd for Peace, which was granted him; and it was call'd the Peace of RESWICK.
VII. Not long after dy'd JAMES, who had been King of BRITAIN.
VIII. Now LEWIS hoping to accom∣plish his Ends, prostituted the Faith he had made, and set up the suppos'd Son of James, to be King of Scotland, England, and Ire∣land.
IX. This provok'd the Indignation of the Confederates, and their Spirits were mov'd thereat.
X. Whereupon a second War broke out, and the Forces were assembl'd together, and they enter'd into the Plains, and many were killed on both Sides.
XI. Every Winter, when the Weather was too cold to keep in open Fields,
XII. King William return'd to England.
XIII. And being well stricken in Years, the Toils and Fatigues of many Campaigns sat heavy upon him; for he had been a War∣rior from his Youth upwards:
XIV. And He sicken'd, and kept his Bed, and perceiving that the Time of his Disso∣lution drew nigh, he sent for his next Suc∣cessor,

XV. And he spent two Days in giving her wholesome Advice and Instructions, and in recommending wise Counsellors unto her: And having establish'd the true Worship of the most High, and settl'd the Nation in such Ease and Prosperity, as the People had
not seen for many Years; He gave up the Ghost, and died in a good old Age.

XVI. All the Kingdom was griev'd for the Loss of him; they mourn'd and wept bitter∣ly, for he had been the Instrument under God, which had redeem'd them from Bon∣dage, and had restor'd unto them their Li∣berty.

DIV2.HEAD: CAAP. VIII.
DIV2.P: QUeen Anne succeeded King William.
II: And coming to the Throne of her Ancestors, she proclaimed War against the King of the Gauls: forasmuch, as he had of∣fered an Indignity to her, in setting up a Pretender to her Realms,
III Which Tidings being brought unto King Lewis, who was then at Dinner,
IV. He looked up to Heaven, and crossing himself, said,
V. Sweet Virgin, have Mercy upon me; it is manifest that I am now grown old, for even the Women do proclaim War against me,
VI. And they prepared their Arms for Battle,
VII. Now Queen Anne choose unto her self a Captain, whose Name was John,

VIII. The same was a great Warrior, and
a skilful Man, a Lover of his Countrey, and one who feared the Lord;
IX. And he went forth, and fought the Queen's Battles: and slew Thousands, and Ten Thousands of her Enemies, and put the rest to Flight

X. He took Tallard Prisoner, who was Captain of the Gauls, and their Ensigns and Trophies of War at Hockstet, and drove the rest of his Foes down to the River Danube, wherein many were drowned, and the Place is called Hockstet unto this Day,
XI. Many more Battles were fought by him, the Particulars of which should I go a∣bout to relate, I fear I should not have room enough to contain them,
XII. Moreover he laid Siege to their strong Towns, and to their Castles; and sacked every one of them,
XIII. He undertook nothing in which he did not prosper, for the Lord was with him in all he did,
XIV. About this Time Corah, one of the Priests of the Temple began to preach publickly,
XV. He was a Stirrer up of Sedition, and a Mover of the People,
XVI. The Father was set against the Son, and the Son envied the Father,

XVII. Their Divisions were many, their
Breaches were wide: and there was no Chri∣stianity, no Brotherly Love among them,
XVIII. They cried out, The Temple of the Lord, the Temple of the Lord is in Danger.
XIX. This did Corah, and all his Fol∣lowers, that they might set upon the Throne the supposed Son of James.
XX. Now it came to pass, that Queen Anne was prevailed upon to change her Mi∣nistry.
XXI. She turned out those who had ser∣ved her faithfully, and from that Time for∣ward her Affairs did not prosper,
XXII. She placed in their Room Persons who deceived her; they imposed upon her, for she was but a Woman,
XXIII. They sold their Country, they betray'd the Nation, they were paving the Way to bring in Idolatry, which is the A∣bomination of the Lord.
XXIV. They made a base, scandalous, and dishonourable Peace; they forsook their Friends, and suffer'd to be massacred the brave People of CATALONIA, who had fought for them.
XXV. They had gotten the Power into their own Hands, they did what they list, and said among themselves, Who is he that can stand against us?
XXVI. They were Confederates with the King of the GAULS, and he tempted them with Gold.
XXVII. They had not God in all their Thoughts, but were led away by the Wiles of Satan.
XXVIII. But the Race is not always to the Swift, nor the Battle unto the Strong: For it is better to trust in the Lord, than put any Confidence in the Arm of Flesh,
XXIX. Wherefore the Lord cut them short in the midst of their Career, and dis∣appointed them of all their Hopes.
XXX. For Queen ANNE dy'd; and some of her evil Councellors fled into a strange Land, knowing the Evil which they had done, and others were put into Prison.
XXXI. She was bury'd in the Tomb of her Ancestors, and Good King GEORGE Reign'd in her Stead.
